Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase II: Clean, Inexpensive, and Carbon-free Energy from a Toxic Waste
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project proposes to
commercialize a new process to recycle petroleum toxic wastes to clean and inexpensive
energy. This Phase II project will scale the improved process by modifying the company?s pilot
unit to incorporate the enhancements realized with the bench scale unit in Phase I. The basic
SuperATR is a non‐catalytic process that employs a cyclic flow reactor filled with an inert packed
bed. In the cyclic flow reactor, the direction of oxidizer/fuel mixture is periodically reversed
producing a high temperature volume. The modifications in the Phase I project effectively
raised the temperature even higher to make the reactor even more efficient.

The broader impacts of this research are that deteriorating qualities of oils and gases is forcing
the petroleum sector to incur very high cost for energy and waste disposal. For example, the
benign disposal of hydrogen sulfide costs oil refineries and natural gas processing plants $5
billion a year. Present technologies only permit extracting the sulfur content while wasting the
much more valuable hydrogen portion. In commercializing this technology, the value
propositions are but not limited to:
 Obtain 9 billion kilowatt hours of carbon‐free electricity and steam inexpensively.
 Lowering gasoline and diesel prices, even by 1 cent per gallon, would leave $2 billion in
the hands of Americans.
 Eliminate 5 million tons of greenhouse gas along with 1.5 million tons of acid rain
pollutants by helping refineries and natural gas plants exceed environmental standards.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this Phase II Small Business Innovative Research project, Innovative Energy Solution is scaling its SuperATR bench-scale reactor to the pilot plant level.  The Phase I bench-scale reactor achieved another significant milestone: a 38% yield of hydrogen from hydrogen sulfide.  The obtained hydrogen sulfide-to-hydrogen yield is the highest ever from a thermal process.

Hydrogen sulfide is a toxic waste that cost the petroleum sector $2.5 billion a year to capture and dispose of.  Present technologies, notably the Claus Process, only permits recovery of the sulfur content while wasting the much more valuable hydrogen portion.  In addition, Claus-based sulfur recovery units emit significant quantities of oxides of sulfur and nitrogen: harmful pollutants that causes acid rain.  Those pollutants are the root cause behind the heavy fines, $2 billion in the last 12 years, 

The SuperATR will not only recover sulfur, it will also extract the much more valuable hydrogen content.  The extracted hydrogen can be utilized to generate clean electricity or used as chemical feedstock for the production of ammonia or methanol.  Unlike the Claus process, it will emit much less other byproducts that causes acid rain.

It its attempt to commercialized the SuperATR process with this Phase II SBIR grant, the team constructed a robust reactor with ten times the capacity of the Phase I reactor.  After construction, the system was tested with natural gas to ascertain operational integrity as well as efficiency. The tests confirm that the reactor operates more efficiently than anticipated.

As part of the commercialization effort, IES is negotiating with a small oil and gas company to install a unit at their sour gas plant in rural Kentucky.  To finance that effort, IES has and still reaching out to a number of potential strategic investors.

The Phase I bench-scale reactor achieved another significant milestone: a 38% yield of hydrogen from hydrogen sulfide. The obtained hydrogen sulfide-to-hydrogen yield is the highest ever from a thermal process. Hydrogen sulfide is a toxic waste that cost the petroleum sector $2.5 billion a year to capture and dispose of. Present technologies, notably the Claus Process, only permits recovery of the sulfur content while wasting the much more valuable hydrogen portion. In addition, Claus-based sulfur recovery units emit significant quantities of oxides of sulfur and nitrogen: harmful pollutants that causes acid rain. Those pollutants are the root cause behind the heavy fines, $2 billion in the last 12 years, The SuperATR will not only recover sulfur, it will also extract the much more valuable hydrogen content. The extracted hydrogen can be utilized to generate clean electricity or used as chemical feedstock for the production of ammonia or methanol. Unlike the Claus process, it will emit much less other byproducts that causes acid rain. It its attempt to commercialized the SuperATR process with this Phase II SBIR grant, the team constructed a robust reactor with ten times the capacity of the Phase I reactor. After construction, the system was tested with natural gas to ascertain operational integrity as well as efficiency. The tests confirm that the reactor operates more efficiently than anticipated. As part of the commercialization effort, IES is negotiating with a small oil and gas company to install a unit at their sour gas plant in rural Kentucky. To finance that effort, IES has and still reaching out to a number of potential strategic investors. Last Modified: 01/10/2018 Submitted by: Jacques P Bingue
